conclusion: Analyzing Elevator Motion at t=4.5s to determine weightlessness or overload
Understanding the Acceleration-Time Graph
From t=0s to t=1s: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s²
From t=1s to t=4s: Constant acceleration of 2 m/s²
From t=4s to t=5s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0
From t=5s to t=55s: Zero acceleration (constant velocity)
From t=55s to t=56s: Acceleration drops to -2 m/s²
From t=56s to t=59s: Constant acceleration of -2 m/s²
From t=59s to t=60s: Acceleration increases from -2 m/s² to 0
Analysis for t=4.5s
At t=4.5s, acceleration is decreasing linearly from 2 m/s² to 0
At t=4.5s, a = 1 m/s² (midpoint)
Determining Weightlessness vs. Overload
Apparent weight formula: F_apparent = mg + ma
For normal weight: F_apparent = mg
Weightlessness occurs when F_apparent = 0, which happens when a = -g
Overload occurs when F_apparent > mg, which happens when a > 0
At t=4.5s, a = 1 m/s² (positive, upward acceleration)
F_apparent = m(g + a) = m(9.8 + 1) = 10.8m N
Since F_apparent > mg, passengers experience an overload condition
At t=4.5s, the elevator is in a state of overload (superweight)
